message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a chemical burn in the eye, and immediate irrigation of the affected eye with saline should be started to prevent further damage. CT orbits and surgical debridement are not indicated in this case, and visual acuity test can be done after irrigation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of a chemical getting into his eye and is experiencing burning and redness. The most appropriate next step in management is irrigation to remove the chemical and prevent further damage to the eye. CT orbits and surgical debridement are not necessary at this time, and a visual acuity test can be performed after irrigation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with chemical exposure to the eye and the most appropriate next step is immediate irrigation to prevent further damage. CT orbits and surgical debridement are not necessary at this time, and a visual acuity test can be performed after irrigation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The most appropriate next step in management for a chemical injury to the eye is immediate irrigation with copious amounts of saline or water to remove the chemical and prevent further damage. CT orbits and surgical debridement are not indicated at this time. A visual acuity test should be performed after irrigation to assess for any vision changes.

We refer to UpToDate for help. Irrigation with saline or water is the most appropriate next step in management for chemical eye injuries to remove the chemical from the eye and prevent further damage. CT orbits and surgical debridement are not indicated at this time, and visual acuity test can be performed after irrigation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Irrigation is the most appropriate next step to immediately flush out any remaining chemicals in the eye. CT orbits or surgical debridement may be necessary if there is evidence of significant ocular damage, but irrigation should be the first step. Visual acuity test may be done after irrigation to assess any damage to the eye.

CT orbits and surgical debridement are not indicated in this case, and while a visual acuity test may be important, irrigation should be the first priority.

CT orbits or surgical debridement would not be the first step in management, and a visual acuity test can be performed after irrigation to assess potential damage to the eye.

Irrigation is the most appropriate first step in management to flush out the chemical and prevent further damage. CT orbits or surgical debridement would not be indicated at this time, and a visual acuity test may be performed after irrigation.
